input: Share video: Fine-tuning LLMs with MLX
writing_steps:
Step 1: Purpose and Audience
- Purpose: Share a video resource on fine-tuning large language models (LLMs) using MLX. Educate and surface a useful resource/tool for people working with AI models.
- Audience: AI engineers, ML practitioners, and developers interested in LLMs and tooling.

Step 2: Wireframe
[Teasing utility of the resource]
[What the video/tool covers and who it's for]
[Link to video]
[Practical CTA: ask what resources readers use or feedback on MLX]

Step 3: Body (Meat)
MLX is becoming a go-to library for running and fine-tuning LLMs on Apple hardware. If you’re looking to get started with hands-on fine-tuning, this video breaks down the practical steps using MLX from setup to training a model.

Step 4: CTA
What other LLM fine-tuning tools or workflows have you found useful?

Step 5: Hook Directions
A. [Tool spotlight]: Fine-tuning LLMs on Mac just got easier
B. [Direct question]: Are you using MLX for LLMs yet?
C. [How-to]: How to fine-tune LLMs with MLX (step-by-step video)
D. [Community angle]: Sharing an underrated resource for LLM fine-tuning on Apple hardware
E. [User’s phrasing]: Fine-tuning LLMs with MLX

Step 5B: Notes
A. Highlight the accessibility and newness for Mac/MLX users.
B. Engage developers familiar with Mac or looking for new tools.
C. Direct, practical, with a how-to angle for hands-on readers.
D. Invite community participation and sharing resources.
E. User’s phrasing: direct and to-the-point.

Step 5C: Pick the best direction: A (Tool spotlight) is clear and relevant for Shaw’s audience.

Final Hook: Fine-tuning LLMs on Mac just got easier with MLX.

Step 6: Draft Post
Fine-tuning LLMs on Mac just got easier with MLX.

MLX is becoming a go-to library for running and fine-tuning large language models on Apple hardware. If you want to get started with hands-on fine-tuning, this video covers the process using MLX—from setup to training a model.

Check out the video here: [insert video link]

What other LLM fine-tuning tools or workflows have you found useful?

Step 7: Review
- One em dash present (“—”). Used for flow and clarity.
- No repeated hook/body lines.
- Practical, not motivational or reflective.
- Stepwise process and factual tone match style examples.
- CTA is specific and singular.
- No clichés, idioms, or figurative language.
- Cross-checked with Examples 1 & 5: aligns with sharing resources and educational tools.

Step 8: Final Post
final_post:

MLX is quickly becoming a go-to library for running and fine-tuning large language models on Apple hardware. If you’re looking to try hands-on fine-tuning, this video walks through the process using MLX—from setup to training a model.
